screens.text: The spread calculator shows you max profit, max loss, and breakeven BEFORE you trade. Never guess again.

screens.headline: Know your numbers before you trade
screens.text: Every spread has four critical numbers: Max Profit, Max Loss, Breakeven, and Probability of Profit. The spread calculator computes all four instantly. You should NEVER enter a spread without knowing these numbers.

screens.headline: Would you drive without a speedometer?
screens.text: Imagine driving with no dashboard - no speedometer, no fuel gauge, no warning lights. That's trading spreads without calculating your risk metrics first. The spread calculator is your trading dashboard. It shows exactly what you're risking, what you can make, and where you breakeven. Professional traders NEVER skip this step.

screens.question: For a bull call spread: Buy $100 call ($12), Sell $110 call ($5). What's the max profit?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! Width ($10) - Debit ($7) = $3 max profit. At expiration, if stock is above $110, both calls are ITM. Your $100 call is worth $10 more than your $110 call, but you paid $7, so profit = $3.
screens.explanation_wrong: Formula: Width of spread - Net debit. Width = $110 - $100 = $10. Debit = $12 - $5 = $7. Max profit = $10 - $7 = $3.

screens.question: Using the calculator, you see a spread has 2:1 risk/reward (risk $1000, make $500). What does this tell you?
options: This is a credit spread with high probability
This is a debit spread with high reward
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! When you risk MORE than you can make, it's a credit spread. You're taking the 'insurance company' side. You need a high probability of success to make this work (typically 65-70%).
screens.explanation_wrong: Risk/reward inverted (risk $2 to make $1) means credit spread. Think: insurance company collects $1, occasionally pays out $2. Needs high win rate to work.

screens.headline: Calculate breakeven
screens.question: Bull call spread: Buy $200 call ($18), Sell $220 call ($8). What's the breakeven price?
screens.explanation: Breakeven = Long strike + Net debit. Long strike = $200. Debit = $18 - $8 = $10. Breakeven = $200 + $10 = $210. Stock must be above $210 at expiration to profit.
screens.teaching_point: For bull call spreads: BE = Long strike + Debit. For bear put spreads: BE = Long strike - Debit.

cards.back: Debit: Long premium - Short premium (you pay). Credit: Short premium - Long premium (you collect).
